Protip: a longer cable means more signal strength loss over the length. Though this is minimal say under 400 ft until after which the signal needs a boost.

The cable length limit is specified as part of the Ethernet standard, exceeding the specifications could introduce sub-optimal performance.  If you need to go beyond 100 meters you can either introduce a repeater or switch in between two cable lengths, or consider fiber, which can support lengths of several miles (light travels faster than electrons on a wire).

The specification of 328 feet has to do with collision detection, so it is a timing thing not a signal strength thing.  Lots of info can be found online as this has been part of the standard for a long time.

If you are trying to make your network perform better I would recommend checking out the details.

The physicist in me is compelled to point out that electrons don't move very fast in a wire, as they really only move in the ballpark of millimeters per *hour*. The signal itself moves significantly faster of course (percentages of the speed of light), but individual electrons don't actually move much.

Heyo,

WiFi can have better performance depending on the provider. However, it's far more likely to look at your local hardware to see if your WiFi is good or not. 

Are you on a USB dongle that barely has any power to the antenna, and thereby needs to be within 15 feet for a good, stable connection? Do you have a laptop with a pretty strong build in antenna? Do you have a PCI-e wifi card with multiple antennas?

How about the router? Is it the generic router your ISP provided? Those usually have low range and low power and low number of bands for your WiFi to connect and operate on. Or did you spend some money on a new router? Multiple antennas? Is it SUPERCHARGED™!? **ULTRACHARGED**™!!!? 

How many other devices are connected to it? Is there another piece of equipment that can cause interference nearby, like a cordless phone, a microwave, etc? 

WiFi is great for convenience. Watch TV, download a game from the couch, check your email or FB from wherever, since most internet requests don't really care about lost packets or delayed packets, it'll just get sent again. Buffering is awesome for tasks like that. However, games really need packet 1 to come before packet 2, which comes before packet 3, etc. WiFi makes it somewhat often that your game has to be put on a very brief hold while you get one singular packet again, and then super-speed chugs through the other packets it was waiting to process to get back up to proper time again.

Using an ethernet connection prevents most sources of interference and loss from your environment. At that point, you will only lose packets and have ping spikes if your router/modem, ISP, or Riot has issues, not because your cat plays with your WiFI dongle and causes a ping spike. (Of course, he could play with the cord and gnaw through it, but that's another story).  

If your WiFi works perfectly fine, awesome! No need to do any changes, enjoy it :) But if you're seeing some spikes, possible disconnections every now and then, you may want to look at improving your WiFi connection at home, or possibly testing out an Ethernet cable and seeing if that's any better.

Great article! If anyone is having connection issues while playing, I recommend heading over to the [Connection Troubleshooting Log Reader](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/209765743-Connection-Troubleshooting-Log-Reader). There, you can submit the Network logs from your match(es) and the log reader will show if you were having ping spikes and packet loss and provide solutions.

You can also narrow down the source of high latency or packet loss by downloading the [WinMTR Network Diagnostic Tool](http://winmtr.net/download-winmtr/), then use that to run a traceroute (for 5-15 minutes) to your server's IP found on the [Network Guide](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752674-Network-System-and-League-of-Legends-Logs). You can run tracerts and pings manually, but an MTR gets it over a duration which will catch and display intermittent issues easier.

Why does Wifi cause so many packets lost?

The real issue with WiFi definitely has more to do with packet loss than adding latency to the experience.  WiFi is radio for data, and just like radio sometimes there is interference that makes it hard to hear what is being said or broadcast.  

Imagine two people in a large empty room having a conversation.  It probably does not matter where they are standing in the room, but if there is no other source of sound, the two people can easily have a clear conversation without any issues.

Now add 100 more people into the room and all trying to have conversations at the same time.  Things get really noisy, really fast.  How close two people are to each other and how loud everyone else is, will impact how successful the original two people can carry on their conversation.  They may even have to repeat what they say several times.

Packet loss works the same way.  If a computer sends a packet to another computer, but the other computer never receives it, then the packet ends up getting re-transmitted.  And taking longer to get there, which adds to the latency.

Because radio waves are being used to transmit the data back and forth, and since there are a limited number of different radio frequencies (channels) that can be used, there are lots of opportunities for interference and congestion which can lead to packets not getting delivered the first time they are sent.

Ethernet cables are like traditional telephone land lines, you generally only have two people on the call.  So as long as you have a good cable, you should have no trouble hearing what is being said.  There can be hundreds of other phone conversations taking place on cables right next to yours, but they will not impact your conversation.  But even on cables sometimes things need to be repeated, just not as often.

Another thing about WiFi, is many of the older WiFi adapters use the 2.4GHz radio band which has a limited number of channels.  There is also a 5GHz band with more channels and is generally less congested, which can deliver a better WiFi experience.  But both the router and the computer's WiFi adapter need to be capable and configured to use the 5GHz band to take advantage of this.

There are a number of other factors involved in how packet loss happens on WiFi, but hopefully this gives you some understanding to what is happening.

I started off with WiFi, which was causing constant spikes due to my computer being upstairs and my router being downstairs. I decided to try buying a long cat6 lan cable that I ran to my computer, which in turn provided much better ping and only one spike every 5 or so games. I am confident that my LAN connection is so much better than WiFi, and I will never switch back to WiFi for League.

I do the same thing.  When I play ranked at night I run a cable across my floor from router to laptop.  It's not pretty (I clean it up before morning so my wife doesn't get annoyed), but very effective at improving my connection.

You could try the AC/LAN converter plug if the constant cable management gets tiring. You can jack both modules into a power socket on the same circuit, then connect a LAN cable from the wall socket to your laptop to connect on Ethernet. May be more convenient and less of a tripping hazard, with possible permanence.

Satellite is the most cost effective means of getting internet in remote places and is not great for online gaming (except maybe turn based games) for the very reasons you note.  There are more costly point-to-point microwave services available that businesses sometimes use, if you really want to play on a better connection, but the cost is pretty significant.

You might try playing on an old school modem service (dial up).  League does not require much in the way of bandwidth for game play. A 56 Kbps modem connection might be better than trying to play on satellite, but no promises. (and, I would not recommend trying to download or patch the game over dial up!)

Another idea which might be better than dial up or satellite would be tethering to a cell phone's data service.  We have reports of some players being able to play in this fashion, but it will use up your data plan pretty fast, so be careful.

I play on many of our regions around the world from our Los Angeles offices, so I thought I knew what it is like to play with high latency.  But satellite? that's gotta be painful, sorry bro...

I have a 50 meg internet plan and play on wifi. Even when no one else is watching videos or playing an online game, my ping is a constant 85 with 360-400 ping spikes about every 5 mins. My room isn't far from the router, so what gives?

Without knowing the details of your setup, I'm going to guess that you're experiencing a fair bit of packet-loss, which is showing up as ping spikes. Even if your room isn't far from the router there could be signal interference caused by other wifi signals, microwaves, or objects between your computer and router. Having a 50 meg internet plan definitely helps with streaming Youtube and Netflix, but having higher bandwidth most likely won't have an impact on lag in League. I'd recommend uploading some of your netlogs to the [Connection Troubleshooting Log Reader](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/209765743-Connection-Troubleshooting-Log-Reader) to see if you're experiencing both ping and packet-loss spikes. If you are, then it might be worthwhile investing in an ethernet cord. You can also reach out to Riot Player Support if you continue having issues!
